Award.AbstractNarration:
The Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES) Annual Meeting will be held in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania from October 16-19, 2019, and anticipating over 4,500 participants. The meeting will feature 19 Program Tracks with the theme "Connecting Communities: Bioengineering Locally and Globally". The goal of the meeting is to encourage innovative learning that promotes inclusion from underrepresented populations within the biomedical engineering community, and opportunities that support research in both academia and industry. NSF funds will support networking and small group interactions and will promote increased knowledge of educational opportunities and pathways to success in biomedical engineering.

This grant provides funding for several competitive travel grant programs as well as professional development activities targeted at underrepresented groups and those that may not otherwise be able to participate in the conference. The competitive travel grant programs include: 12 students research awards, 40 career development awards for graduate students, postdoctoral fellows, early career faculty and professionals from underrepresented populations in BME, including junior faculty; and 20 NSBE members interested in biomedical engineering. Additionally, funding is required for a High School Expo program for students from schools that might not have a STEM curriculum. Finally, funding from NSF will be used to support 15 high school students with chaperones in this activity. Over four days, the 2019 meeting will feature 19 Program Tracks with approximately 950 oral presentations and more than 2,000 poster presentations.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2019 Biomedical Engineering Society (BMES) Annual Meeting was held in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, from October 16-19, 2019. The meeting was a success with 5,625 attendees, making it the highest attended BMES meeting ever held by the Society. The continued popularity of the BMES Annual Meeting speaks to the growing numbers and interest in the biomedical engineering (BME) community making the Annual Meeting an important venue for bringing together top researchers, universities, and industry representatives.

At the 2019 BMES Annual Meeting, the NSF conference award funds supported 51 participants. This included 30 travel awards (8 Student Research Awards, 16 Career Development Awards, and 6 Travel Awards for student members of the National Society for Black Engineers), which enabled BMES to engage more undergraduate and graduate students, postdoctoral trainees, junior faculty and professionals from underserved communities who may not otherwise have the opportunity to participate in the BMES Annual Meeting. Funding was also expanded to attract regional underrepresented minority high school students and expose them to BMES and BME by supporting a High School Expo Day at the Annual Meeting.

The High School Expo attracted 31 underrepresented minority high school students and chaperones from the Philadelphia region and beyond to participate in the Annual Meeting on Thursday, October 17th. The start of the Expo included an orientation to discuss what the day would entail and to give the students the chance to make connections with mentors available to answer questions, share their experiences and help guide them through the meeting. NSF funds supported 10 students and 10 chaperones (and 1 partial) to participate in the program, which enabled the students to participate in the BMES State of Society and Pritzker Award Lecture, attend and present posters, visit student chapter tables and exhibitor booths, attend the Diversity Award Lecture, and participate in a variety of student and early career sessions.

The funds from the NSF Conference Grant enabled students and professionals to participate in an array of activities with something available to promote learning for all. Broadening the representation of meeting participants through the funds of the NSF Conference Grant supported increased opportunities for mentoring, career advancement, and learning of educational and professional opportunities. By engaging high school students and their chaperones in activities of the meeting, these funds have also contributed to broader impacts of increasing awareness of BME as a professional discipline.
